data.title: Frasier's John Mahoney Passed away
data.meta_description: John Mahoney article.Â  I remember when he was the father of Bruce Willis in Striking DistanceÂ  I remembered I liked that Movie.Â  He was also in TheÂ AmericanÂ Pre
data.text:
Post by Llyan (Admin) on

John Mahoney article. I remember when he was the father of Bruce Willis in Striking Distance I remembered I liked that Movie. He was also in The American President with Michael Douglas.

tvline.com/2018/02/05/john-mahoney-dead-frasier-star-dies/

He was younger than I thought since he tended to play older characters.

FYI: This sucks!

Post by tuna1 on

One thing I didn't know was that he was born in England and didn't become a U.S. citizen until 1959. He got his start in Chicago theater--notably the Steppenwolf Theater of which Gary Sinise was a co-founder.

RIP Mr. Mahoney

Post by Hari Seldon on

John Mahoney article. I remember when he was the father of Bruce Willis in Striking Distance I remembered I liked that Movie. He was also in The American President with Michael Douglas.

And not to forget 'Management' in Burn Notice. A nice departure for him since he wasn't playing the father of any other character and while he was a bad guy, he seemed to be the one staying in between Michael (the main character) and the worse guys.

Post by nas on

He was younger than I thought since he tended to play older characters.

yes, I was surprised when I heard he was only 77 - tho' I remember hearing that a long time ago, and just forgot...

he had an "old face", and that's why he was good at playing "Old Dad"...

in fact, when he played Frazier's dad in that sitcom he was, in fact, only 15 years older than Kelsey Grammer...

kinda' like the actor Len Cariou (born: 1939) who plays the patriarch of the family in Blue Bloods...

he's not nearly old enough to be Tom Selleck's (born: 1945) dad, but he's another "old face" actor, ergo....

agree, NewBe, it does suck! ðŸ˜•

nas

edit to add:

the man must've had a great sense of humor...

he was quoted as saying [about losing his British accent]:

"People say there's no trace of an accent anymore, and there isn't because I worked very hard to lose it. And the reason I did that is a British accent in America is a real status symbol."

very good, Mr Mahoney!

Post by Llyan (Admin) on

One thing I didn't know was that he was born in England and didn't become a U.S. citizen until 1959. He got his start in Chicago theater--notably the Steppenwolf Theater of which Gary Sinise was a co-founder.

RIP Mr. Mahoney

I compare him to John Hillerman who was born in Texas and did a British accent like a native.

John Mahoney born in England, came to the US as a young man and lost his natural accent while serving in the US Army (serving gave him citizenship)

Post by Hari Seldon on

One thing I didn't know was that he was born in England and didn't become a U.S. citizen until 1959. He got his start in Chicago theater--notably the Steppenwolf Theater of which Gary Sinise was a co-founder.

RIP Mr. Mahoney

I compare him to John Hillerman who was born in Texas and did a British accent like a native.

John Mahoney born in England, came to the US as a young man and lost his natural accent while serving in the US Army (serving gave him citizenship)

And Hollywood is running out of actors who served it seems.
